speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (11.17 A.m.)
theText: I want to make a few remarks on the reportWednesday,8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1901 on 27 February when the matter was debated there. The prime reason I wanted to rise was that there was a recommendation in the report which I thought needed to be addressed. The recommendation is on page 20 of the report. It reads: 1. the Department of Employment, Education and Training examine all the issues relevant to its funding of the National Thai Studies Centre at the Australian National University, with a view to ensuring its continued operation under conditions no less favourable than those which have applied to date. I want to say a little about that recommendation and about the importance, as I see it, of maintaining a capacity for us to teach Thai in Australian universities. The Thai studies centre at the Australian National University has done an outstanding job. I understand that there is some scepticism within DEET as to whether or not funding should continue, and I think that is a great pity. From my knowledge of Thailand and the communications we have there, it is foolish for us to ignore such an important trading partner and a country so important to our relations with ASEAN, and to not have the continuity of such an excellent centre. I will come to that in a moment. Before dealing with that, I want to comment on a few other aspects of the report. Obviously, in this year of remembrance of the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, it was particularly moving for those of us who had not previously visited Hellfire Pass or the Kanchanaburi War Cemetery to do so. The present surrounds in the tropical Asianjungle are very benign, and it is very hard to envisage the trauma and suffering of those Australians who worked on the Burma railway. . We saw, of course, only that small part of the railway where Weary Dunlop's ashes were scattered, where the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) opened a memorial and where-thanks to the work by a number of members of the Australia-Thai Chamber of Commerce, including Mr Rob Beattie and Major Allan Lowe and others-there is a very worthwhile facility which ensures that those who are Australian or have an interest in the area will be able to visit in an appropriate way. That is something that needs to be recognised more widely in Australia. The honourable member for Casey( Mr Halverson) referred to access to Hellfire Pass and to the facilities that have been installed there. The events at Hellfire Pass forged a special relationship between Thailand and Australia during World War II. It is a relationship on which we can still build in 1995 and in the years ahead. Certainly, there is recognition of the deaths of those young Australians in Thailand. The relationship that was developed at a personal level at that time gives us the opportunity to develop our relationship in the future. I reiterate that anyone who visits a war cemetery, wherever it might be around the world, could not help but be impressed by the way in which the cemeteries are maintained. Those whose relatives died in battlefields overseas, wherever they might be, can be assured that their loved ones have been cared for in an appropriate manner. The delegation also visited Laos. The leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Reid( Mr Ferguson), has already made some observations about that visit. I will not say a great deal, except to point out that Laos is an important country in the region. It has a special relationship with Australia. We were very grateful to the Australian ambassador in Laos for his assistance during our visit, and that gratitude is referred to in the report. It is important to distinguish between Thailand arid Laos. As a result of the Friendship Bridge, there is greater contact between the two countries. Because the people are ethnically similar and their languages are akin, the Laotians tend to feel that they are going to be overwhelmed by the Thais. I do not think that fear is surprising, considering the nature of the MC 1902 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 March 1995 respective peoples. However, it is important that Australia provides help wherever it can in developing the infrastructure which will enable Laos to develop its capacity to make decisions for the future. I, for one, am very impressed with the way in which Australia has provided help in a meaningful way in the past. The type of AIDAB aid that has been provided needs to be developed in the future as we look at ways in which the benefits that flow from the Friendship Bridge, which crosses the Mekong" can be used to bring the countries of Asia, and certainly Laos and Thailand, closer together. As the honourable member for Reid observed during his speech on Monday, when the delegation visited Thailand there was a good deal of controversy over a statement that had been made by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) regarding relationships between the Thai military and the Khmer Rouge. That was definitely a matter of considerable sensitivity to the Thais. Almost everype'rson we met made some reference to that, and there were several fairly strong verbal attacks on us and on Senator Gareth Evans as a result of that comment. On each of those occasions we explained the circumstances. We stressed that the matter was of real concern because of the nature of Australia's commitment t6 Cambodia. We said that we hoped that across-the-border aid was not being given. My concern was with the way in which Senator Gareth Evans made the remarks and then had to virtually withdraw them. I felt that that acted contrary to the way in which Australia should deal with Asian people. Asians are very conscious of face. I suppose we all are-and probably none more so than politicians. However, loss of face is a real problem when dealing with Asians. Ifan allegation is to be made, it really needs to be dealt with in a way where the accusation can be made and can be registered with those who might be able to do something about it. I was concerned about the way in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs raised the allegations about the association, and with how his withdrawal meant that it was Senator Gareth Evans who lost face. I do not know the detail of the time at which the Thais ceased having that contact with the Khmer Rouge. But from the very reaction of the Thais, I suspect that there has been quite extensive contact between at least the Thai military arid the Khmer Rouge. I do not doubt for one minute that the accuracy of Senator Evans's. comment was such that he verified the comments before he made them. This situation indicates yet again the relevance of the recommendation we made about the National Thai Studies Centre. A recommendation I made long since to the Australian Defence Force Academy was that it should be a prerequisite that every young sailor, soldier and air force officer going through that academy have at least one year of training in an Asian language or in Asian culture. It is paramount that, as we move into a world where demonstrably we are going to be dealing much more significantly with Asia than we have in the past, we understand how to deal with the Asians. We have to understand that there are so many ways in which they are fundamentally different from us: not only are the languages that they speak different but also they have a different cultural base and from that culture they so often have a different vision of the future. Those of us who have had contact with people in Asian countries wiII understand that when a Japanese person, for example, says 'Yes' he means that he has heard you but not that he Wednesday,8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1903 approves of what you say. Other Asian races have different mannerisms and they react differently from the way that we Westerners tend to react. It is important that we try to deal with them in a way which takes account of their sensitivities, their prejudices, their religious backgrounds, their cultural ideas and any other aspects. It is for these reasons that the National Thai Studies Centre is so important. I would be very disappointed if the Department of Employment, Education and Training withdraws funding from that centre. From what I have seen of that centre-and representatives of the centre have given evidence to the committee on a number of occasions-I think it is doing a remarkable job. Sadly, while there has generally been a growth in Asian languages in our schools and our universities, Thai is one of the lesser. of the languages and yet it is a very important vehicle to understanding when doing deals with the Thai people. Of course, there are great opportunities for the development of relationships with Thailand and one aspect of that emerged in discussions we had with the Australian-Thai Chamber of Commerce. I have been one of those who have been very critical of Westpac in recent years but Gary White, the Chief Representative of Westpac in Bangkok, almost restored my faith in that bank. Westpac was one of the first banks to enter into local business dealings in Taipei and in Taiwan. In fact, Westpac had established quite a significant network. Being the first bank there, it had acquired a very good reputation. It was doing business and it was operating profitably. But blow me down if Westpac did not decide to withdraw from the Taiwan market ata time when we were trying to promote our commercial contacts, and Taiwan is a very important market for Australia. Not only did Westpac withdraw but it sold its business to a Belgian bank. Here we are saying that we have got continuing interests, and Westpac sells out to a Belgian bank and we allow the Europeans to come in under our neck. I felt that was totally inappropriate. Therefore, when I m-t Gary White, the representative of Westpac in Bangkok, I was more than a little apprehensive. However, I thought that Gary White was outstanding, as were each of the members of the Australian-Thai Chamber of Commerce who met us that day. Mr Terry Adams of Linfox Logistics Thailand gave an excellent overview of the transport potential there. Without going into it too much, in Thailand, people unfortunately use 10-wheel trucks which are grossly inefficient. They clog the streets of Bangkok and they contribute to all of the traffic problems. There are ways by which, demonstrably, the traffic flow in Thailand, and particularly Bangkok, can and should be improved. I was quite fascinated to see a stranger making recommendations, one of which is to get rid of these 10-wheel trucks and to start introducing a reasonable means of moving goods and people around the place. At that meeting of the Australian-Thai Chamber of CommerceI thought each of us learnt a great deal. I have only identified two members but there were a number of other very impressive representatives, including Will Hamilton of Thai Leighton, Alex Tan of Telstra, and Chris Leon of Thai Industrial Gases. They all brought to us a refreshing approach. I mention that morning meeting because I know the honourable member for Throsby( Mr Hollis) adverted to it. It is important that, in dealing with politics, we understand the different prejudices of those who are in business. Gary White, in his address, raised the issue that Senator Evans's comments had affected Australian business contacts. In no way should a government be inhibited in making comments on political issues, but, at the same time, it is very important that the Australian government takes into account the sensitivities of people in the region. This is, again, a fair stretch of the MC 1904 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,8 March 1995 bow, but I know that, in some of the Middle East countries, some of the comments which have been made have prejudiced Australian business which is done in those communities. I am worried that the foreign minister, in making those remarks-no doubt with absolute verification of what he said-has prejudiced Australia's standing in Thailand in an .unfortunate way. Perhaps if Senator Evanswent along to the National Thai Studies Centre at the AND for a little while it may give him some better understanding of how to deal with Asian people. Australia's J;"elations with Thailand are very important to us The meeting with the Australia-Thai Chamber ofComrrierce gave us an idea of the excellent job that Australians are doing in Thailand. There are great opportunities in Thailand, but it is unfortunate that some of the commercial contacts which came about as a result of the construction of the Friendship Bridge do not seem to have brought on the flow in construction work that we hoped for. Of course, wherever you are in Asia, or indeed wherever you are overseas, Australian companies have got to understand that they have to persist in their efforts. You cannot go for a one-week visit and think that everything is going to flow from that. You have got to be able to provide a backup service and to recognise the sensitivities of the countries concerned. Companies cannot take business for granted just because there may be a window of opportunity. Australia has a great future in Thailand. The report by the· Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the visit to Thailand and Laos will help towards putting Australia's relationship with those countries into perspective for the future. I commend the chairman of the committee, and I thank Patrick Regan, the secretary of the committee, for the help he provided to the members of the committee during the visit. Debate (on motion by Mr Hicks) adjourned. Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee Exposure draft on section 53(3) of the Constitution Debate resumed from 6 March 1995, on motion by Mr Melham: That the House take note of the paper. which the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs considered relevant to the interpretation of the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. I also briefly outlined a number of the committee's major recommendations, and I will now discuss some aspects of the committee's report in more detail. As the third paragraph of section 53 is part of the scheme of that section, it is often impossible to discuss the paragraph in isolation from the other paragraphs in section 53. The fifth paragraph of section 53 states: Except as provided in this section, the Senate shall have equal power with the House of Representatives in respect of all proposed laws. The third paragraph of section 53 is one such exception. It provides: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Melham (Banks) (11.38 A.m.)
theText: During my tabling statement. I outlined the factorsWednesday, 8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1905 The broad purpose of section 53 of the constitution is to preserve the financial initiative of the House of Representatives. This is the focus of a number of the committee's recommendations. Under the constitution, it is the prerogative of the House of Representatives to initiate taxing and appropriation bills. This principle derives from sections 53 and 56 of the constitution. Section 53 prohibits bills which appropriate revenue or money and bills which impose taxation from being originated in the Senate. It also limits the power of the Senate to amend bills. Section 56 of the constitution gives the executive government holding the majority in the House of Representatives control in relation to the expenditure of public money. The initiative in relation to money matters is vested in the lower House in all Commonwealth countries. This rule is regarded as a safeguard against unrestrained and politically competitive financial proposals by members of parliament who do not have the responsibility of government. However, despite this rule, all financial bills must pass both houses before being presented to the Governor General for assent. While the House of Representatives has an exclusive right of initiation, the Senate has the power of veto. There appeared to be general agreement among participants in the inquiry that the purpose of section 53 is to preserve the financial initiative of the House of Representatives. The clerks of both houses agree with this principle. In a submission to the committee the clerk of this House, Mr Lyn Barlin, quoted House of Representatives Practice in stating that the financial initiative rule vests the right to initiate and the right to move to increase appropriations and taxes with the government-see page S191 of volume 1 of submissions to the inquiry. The Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, also agreed with the financial initiative rule. In a submission to theinquiry, commenting on the government's interpretation of section 53 in relation to Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1994, Mr Evans noted that the purpose of section 53 is to preserve the financial initiative of the House of Representatives-see pages S65 and S219 of submissions to the inquiry. If senators also agree with this fundamental principle, the prospect of the houses drafting a compact embodying that principle may be likely. As part of the process of examining the issues associated with the inquiry, the committee held a seminar in Canberra on 28 October last year. The participants in the seminar included Mr Dennis Rose QC, Professor Cheryl Saunders, Professor Anthony Blackshield, Dr Jim Thomson, Ms Hilary Penfold, Mr Barlin, Mr Evans and the committee's consultant, Professor Michael Coper, as well as members of the committee. One of the issues discussed at the seminar was the justiciability of section 53. This issue is important in determining the scope of the houses to negotiate a compact concerning the interpretation of the third paragraph of section 53. The traditional view is that section 53 is not justiciable. That is, a court cannot intervene in a legislative process if the requirements of .section 53 are not being complied with. Furthermore, a law which has been passed by both houses and has received royal assent is not invalid if it does not comply with section 53. The traditional view is based on the deliberate reference to 'proposed laws' in section 53 and section 54. This view is supported by the convention debates and case law. During the convention debates it was suggested that the term 'proposed laws' should be used to indicate that a matter is a question of order between the two houses. . . In Osborne v. the Commonwealth (1911), 12 CLR 321, Chief Justice Sir Samuel Griffith commented that se.ctions 53 and 54 deal with proposed laws-that is, bills or projects of law MC 1906 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,8 March 1995 still under consideration and not assented to-and that they lay down rules to be observed with respect to proposed laws at that stage. Whatever obligations are imposed by those sections are directed to the houses of parliament, whose conduct of their internal affairs is not subject to review by a court of law. Members of the High Court have supported the view that section 53 is not justiciable in a range of decisions. For example, section 53 has been referred to as merely directory and for parliamentary guidance only. While most of the evidence received by the committee supports the view that section 53 is not justiciable, there are some factors which may support the alternative view, namely that section 53 may be justiciable. I will briefly outline some of these factors. The factors are dealt with in more detail in the committee's exposure draft. The first factor is the declining persuasive value of relevant precedents. In Cormack v. Cope (1974), 131 CLR 432, a declaration was sought that the Petroleum and Minerals Authority Bill 1973 was not a proposed law by reference to which the Governor General could dissolve both houses under section 57 of the constitution. Ultimately, a joint sitting was held, and the bill was passed by both houses, sitting together. The validity of the act was then challenged in Victoria v. the Commonwealth and Connor (1975), 134 CLR 81, which is known as the PMA case, on the ground that there had not been compliance with section 57 of the constitution. I do not propose to outline the judgments in each of those cases, but only to comment, in the light of discussion of those cases held during the committee's seminar on section 53. During the seminar, Professor Cheryl Saunders suggested that in Cormack v. Cope and the PMA case the court made it clear that the Australian constitution was a controlled constitution. The court showed a willingness to scrutinise the compliance of the parliamentary process with the constitution, and to intervene, at least once legislation was enacted. Professor Saunders went on to suggest that earlier High Court precedents on sections 53 and 54 might be less persuasive, following the decisions in these cases-see page 4 of the seminar transcript. A second factor which suggests that section 53 may be justiciable is the interrelationship between section 53 and other sections of the constitution. In Osborne v. the Commonwealth, His Honour Justice Higgins queried why an act is invalid by reason of its substance under section 55 if it deals with matters other than the imposition of taxation, when a bill appropriating moneys for the ordinary annual services of the government is not invalid by reason of its substance under section 54. This comment was referred to on a number of occasions during the committee's public hearings, and lends support to the argument that section 54 should be considered justiciable. It has been suggested that there may be some lack of logic in finding the rule in section 55, but not that in section 54, justiciable. If section 54 were found to be justiciable, that could, arguably, open the door to judicial review of section 53, as well-again, see page 4 of the seminar transcript. . The third factor relevant to thepossiblejusticiability of section 53 is the increasing emphasis on principles of responsible government. During the seminar, Professor Blackshield suggested that the justiciability of section 53 has become more of an open question, because the High Court is shifting ground, to some extent, in terms of basic constitutional theory. The traditional model of responsible government involves judicial deference to parliament. But Professor Blackshield suggested that, when the High Court discusses representative government, it has in mind a strong conception that all arms of government have their own Wednesday, 8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1907 direct responsibility to the Australian people. As part of that conception, the High Court may be more willing to insist on adherence to the constitution, even by parliament itself-see pages 10 and 11 of the seminar transcript. There have also been two recent High Court cases where the justiciability of certain constitutional provisions has been at issue. The justiciability of section 54 of the constitution was raised in Northern Suburbs General Cemetery Reserve Trust v. the Commonwealth (19921993), 176 CLR 555, known as the Northern Suburbs case. The joint judgment referred to the traditional view that failure to comply with a procedural provision, such as section 54, is not justiciable. However, as there had been compliance with section 54, the court did not deal with whether the section was justiciable. Issues concerning the third paragraph of section 53 are currently before the High Court in the State of Western Australia v. the Commonwealth, the native title case. It was argued by Western Australia that three Senate amendments to the Native Title Bill contravened the third paragraph of section 53. One of the amendments concerned the insertion of a clause establishing a parliamentary joint committee on native title. Counsel for Western Australia submitted that establishing such a committee would involve a burden on the people, as it would involve various administrative costs and other expenses, revenue for which would be raised by taxation. The parliament awaits with interest any comment on the third paragraph of section 53 by the High Court. The possibility of comment on the issue by the High Court raises further issues. During the seminar, Professor Blackshield suggested that, even if there are justiciable issues associated with section 53, those issues may be limited. The question of whether the High Court has power or jurisdiction to pronounce on certain issues is interlocked with the question of what those issues are. Professor Blackshield went on to say that, in order to have a justiciable question before it, the High Court must be able to identify fairly precise legal questions which are capable of reasonably objective answers, and it must be able to formulate questions without venturing too far into the intramural· business of parliament-see page 7 of the seminar transcript. However, despite the factors which may support the poss.ible justiciability of section 53, the weight of opinion and evidence to the committee suggests that the section is unlikely to be considered justiciable. The committee agrees with this body of opinion. That is a view that I hold, and I hold strongly. As it appears unlikely that section 53 will be the subject of judicial determination, it will be undesirable if there remains no authoritative pronouncement on the interpretation and application of section 53, particularly the third paragraph. That is not to say that section 53 does not impose any constraints on the parliament. As is noted in the report, disregard of these constraints may be immune from con;ection by the High Court. However, an interpretation that flouted section 53 would obviously be unacceptable to both houses. But if the houses did agree to a compaCt that was in flagrant disregard of the constitution, the High Court might then be interested in considering the matter. If the parliament is the judge of whether there has been compliance with the constitutional rules for the passage of money bills through parliament, this puts the onus on the houses to reach agreement in light of the spirit and letter of section 53. . In the committee's view, a compact between the houses would show parliament's fidelity to the constitutional requirements of section 53. The objective of any compact would be MC 1908 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,8 March 1995 twofold-namely, to assist in the practical workings of the parliamentary process, and to define and limit the constitutional powers of both houses. The committee reiterates that any interpretation should be based on a sensible and practical view of section 53 that is reasonably sustainable within the words of that section, and reasonably consistent with history and parliamentary practice. The exposure draft includes a statement of principles for possible inclusion in a compact. It is the committee's view that these principles could form a useful basis for discussion between the houses. However, the committee recognises that both houses will need to be prepared to make concessions to reach a workable agreement. I hope that the exposure draft and the principles contained in it promote discussion both within the parliament and beyond. I look forward to discussions on this matter with members of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and with other interested parties. Following discussions with the Senate committee I look forward to the possibility of the House reaching a formal and workable agreement on the application and interpretation of the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. I emphasise that this matter should be treated seriously as, in my view, section 53 is almost certainly not justiciable; the onus is on the parliament to interpret that section of the constitution. Consequently,each house should take steps to ensure that it discharges its responsibility in this area. It is not good enough to look for excuses and to say that it is too hard to reach a compact and a workable agreement. I believe it can be done. I believe that it is in the interests of the parliament that it should be done, and that people should not walk away from it. I have taken my time to outline the arguments for and against justiciability because, as I said earlier, I am firmly of the view that section 53 is not justiciable and, in my opinion, that places more emphasis on the parliament to look at it and to work towards a compact. That emphasis is not on the government and the Senate, but on the House. of Representatives and the Senate. That is what constitutes the parliament. And if a compact is reached, that is what will be unique about it: it will be a compact between the House of Representatives and the Senate. I believe that it is achievable. To date, the process that the committee has embarked upon has shown that there is goodwill between all interested people involved; that there is a difference of opinion, but that the difference is not so marked or so stark that a workable solution is not achievable. It is achievable. I think that there are some basic principles that can be adhered to and that we can come up with a compact. That is a great step forward for the parliament. I do commend those who have been involved in the preparation of this exposure draft, and I commend that draft to the parliament. of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report The third paragraph a/section 53 a/the constitution: exposure draft. I wish to express my appreciation to the committee chairman, the member for Banks( Mr Melham), for the way in which this inquiry was conducted. ThoughI was a sometime participant, it is an area that anybody who has parliamentary duties must be interested in because it relates so intimately to the comparative powers and responsibilities of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The committee examined the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution, which states: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cadman (Mitchell) (11.53 A.m.)
theText: I welcome this opportunity to speak on the HouseWednesday, 8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1909 The processes the committee adopted were salami-like-and very appropriate-in slicing through the areas of contention and possible interpretation of that paragraph. In August last year, the committee prepared a summary of issues which outlined some of the practical measures that could be confronted by the parliament. I want to mention some of the issues raised when we first came to examine this matter. Is the difference between an amendment and a request for an amendment important in practical terms? Should the Senate refer an amendment to the House of Representatives, or a request for amendment? Are they both regarded as being the same thing? Another issue raised was whether it would be desirable for two committees-one of the Senate and one of the House to draft a protocol detailing the procedures to be implemented when questions concerning the third paragraph of section 53 arise and establishing a mechanism for dispute resolution in such cases. We came to a conclusion. I will read recommendation No. 13, which is the final recommendation of the exposure draft. It says: The Committee recommends that there should be a compact between the Housesthat is the Senate and the House of Representativesin relation to the interpretation and application of provisions of the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution. The Committee further recommends that there should be consultation between the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and this Committeethat is, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitution Affairsin order to determine how negotiations in relation to the compact will proceed. So right at the beginning, where we were looking at the issues, there was the concept that it might be possible for the House and the Senate to work towards an understanding. It has been called a compact. Initially, I think that might be too grand a term. If there is a memorandum of understanding, I propose that that may not cover all possible or foreseeable instances where there is a reference where we can lay down a series of protocols as each issue arises. I would need to refer to the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. Over a period of time we will develop a firm understanding, in the form of a series of agreements, which are much stronger and more binding than sheer conventions, but are agreements gradua,1ly reached by the two Houses-an evolutionary process. It may not be possible for the two committees or for the House and the Senate to reach complete agreement on all areas that relate to section 53. But over a period, as we get particular circumstances arising, we will deal with those and add to the fund of information and the various determinations that go to constitute, finally, what could be called a contract, or a compact, an evolutionary process that may take some years to arrive at. I have no problem with that. The thing to do is make a start. The last thing I would like to see is this area being thrown to the High Court for the High Court to interpret the relationship between the House and the Senate. The committee has come to a conclusion that this area is not justiciable. I think that is the right decision. There appears to be no evidence which would provide an opportunity for the High Court or any other court to become involved in the affairs relating to the charges or burdens decided by the House of Representatives and the Senate. People are very fond of giving responsibilities to the parliament for us to find solutions to things but then, having given those responsibilities to the parliament, people quickly want to MC 1910 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,8 March 1995 re-claim their rights. So the people with the responsibility have their powers to act diminished and are criticised for not being able to do anything. We need to be conscious that the High Court and others, through the process of claiming their rights, are extracting from the parliament powers that they originally wanted the parliament to perform and are thereby diminishing the power and the capacity of the parliament to take action. This is one area that the High Court or any other court should never get into. It must be a matter that is settled between the two houses and the committee. The exposure draft comes to that conclusion. I hope this exposure draft draws a lot of comment and close examination from the community. I have dealt already with some of the practical issues that were raised in the initial stages of our inquiry, the second one being the prospect of two committees joining together and drafting a protocol. With the hindsight of nine months, that is pretty good identification of what can be the issues for the House of Representatives. That issues paper went on to query whether or not a court could intervene if it is considered that a proposed law does not comply with the third paragraph of section 53. Again, the issues paper proposed: What are the consequences for an Act if the requirements of the third paragraph of section 53 have not been complied with? .. Can the Senate press a request for an amendment to a bill? ... What are the legal consequences of the Senate introducing a charge or burden in a bill (which has already been passed by the House of Representatives) and which initially contained no proposal to place a charge or burden on the people? And so, point by point, every possible ramification of the third paragraph of section 53 was dealt with at an early stage, drawing out the prospects of what the interpretations could be. Gradually, through a process of seminar and evidence, the committee reached its conclusions on each one of those areas and finally came to a conclusion that the responsibility does lie with the House and the House should accept those responsibilities; bills that impose charges should not be introduced in the Senate. We moved right away from any loosening up of what the House regards as its full responsibility. The recommendations include that a compact be attempted but some of the other conclusions reached by the committee are as significant as that one. They include: The Committee recommends that the third paragraph of section 53 should be regarded as applicable only to bills that have originated in the House of Representativesand alsoThe Committee recommends that, in relation to appropriations, taxes and other charges, a request should be required where an alteration to a bill is moved in the Senate which will make an increase legally possible (even if the net effect of the alteration is a decrease). That is an absolutely proper interpretation, in my view, of what the third paragraph of section 53 stands for. This is, in some ways, a landmark report that will only be of interest to a narrow number of people until a dispute of some sort arises. When that happens, the whole nation will want to know about the third paragraph of section 53 and why the row is between the Senate and the House and why the House is jacking up because the Senate is seeking powers that do not properly belong to the .senate. Then, I suspect, the government will get involved. Wednesday, 8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1911 It is the recommendation of this committee that I think will ultimately be the real test of how it should go, and that is the recommendation to look at the areas of problem, draw up a compact on which should be handled and how, and leave to one side those areas where there is not going to be an agreement. Let the disputes arise and at that point, if it is necessary, reach a conclusion and the government of the day may get involved. It is not possible to foresee every instance where there will be a dispute or a problem. It is not possible to foresee every interpretation that may need to be placed on the third paragraph of section 53 but the attempt should be made and a compact written. I believe that with goodwill we can confine the area of possible conflict to something that is reasonable. Finally, as a member of the House of Representatives, I think it would be completely inappropriate for governments to put their interpretation on what should happen. This is a matter between the houses-between the members of the House of Representatives and senators: It is what we stand for in our chamber and what they stand for in theirs that has to be settled. It is not a matter where a government or the Attorney-General's Department or anybody else can come along and say, 'This is what we believe should happen.' It should be a vote that is not taken on party lines. An establishment of support for a compact of any type should be a free vote with members acting independently. I see the member for Banks jerk back. Today he has put his name to another landmark report which may not advance his popularity in all quarters, but which is a very important report. If we can consider it as parliamentarians, I do not believe that there are divisions of ideology on this matteL It is only how we feel as members of the House of Representatives. I cannot see the basis of an ideological difference here. The same should apply in the Senate. If we do it in that way, as professional parliamentarians, we will reach a good conclusion. If there is external interference of any sort, the prospect of our reaching that solid base of understanding will be diminished . . I compliment, in particular, the member for Banks and the member for Tangney( Mr Williams) for their effort, and also the staff of the committee. The report is a valuable contribution and I trust that we will have the opportunity of moving ahead with a compact at an early opportunity, perhaps not in this parliament but maybe in the next parliament. Perhaps it might be possible within this parliament to reach an early stage of an agreement between the houses. If that were the case it would be most desirable. It would be a most worthy goal for the legal and constitutional affairs committee of the House of Representatives to achieve an agreement. If we can, it will benefit not only this parliament, but the next one, and the next one, and all parliaments to come. ( Mr Cadman) when he said that this report would be of little interest to the wider public. It is an esoteric report. That is the best way to describe it. It is of interest to lawyers, constitutional lawyers particularly, to the clerks of the houses and to those who like to pore over constitutions, whether they be the constitution of a small association or the constitution of Australia. It is probably noteworthy that the member for Banks( Mr Melham) and the member for Tangney( Mr Williams), both of whom were previously lawyers--one a solicitor like myself, the other a QC and barrister-have churned out some reports just like this one, which are esoteric but interesting. I found this report particularly interesting. I think the member for Mitchell was a solicitor in a former life as well.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Pyne (Sturt) (12.07 P.m.)
theText: Not a truer word was spoken by the member for Mitchell
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cadman
theText: No, no, but I've been converted.MC 1912 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 March 1995 next election, like the member for Robertson ( Mr Walker). An inquiry into the operation of section 53, paragraph 3, is an important inquiry. It is important because it goes to the relationship between the Senate and the House of Representatives. That is why I wanted to support it and do it and be involved with it. It goes to the reasons for the formation of our constitutional relationship as a nation, dividing up the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate was to have important power because it represented the states in a federation. Therefore· it was given overwhelming power to reject legislation-even money bills-and to deny a government supply, as it has done on numerous occasions. On the other hand the Senate was not given the power to initiate money bills and to form policy for government, because it does not have the responsibility of government. Therefore the financial initiative remains with the people's house, the House of Representatives. Primarily, this was designed to avoid the possibility of rivalry between a house that represented the states and a house that represented the people. I know the member for Banks and I share many views in this respect, perhaps unlike some of my other coalition colleagues. It was a very important distinction to make, because the Senate is becoming less and less of a states house, as it was originally designed. It was not to have the same power as a government responsible for financial and taxation decisions. What was the catalyst for the current inquiry? I will quote briefly from the report at paragraph 1.7.1. It sums up the catalyst for the inquiry and the importance of this inquiry: ... the interpretation and application. of the third paragraph of section 53 is a matter of fundamental substantive importance, as it preserves the financial initiative of the House of Representativesas intended by the framers of the Constitution. Proponents of this view suggest that to describe the provisions of section 53 as essentially procedural tends to downplay their importance, as they are requirements of the Constitution which must be respected. I think that is very true. One of the interesting things in this inquiry was the divergence of opinion between the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Clerk of the Senate. One Of them was sugge-ting that it was a procedural matter and, by being procedural, it was no less important than if it were regarded as an important part of the constitution. I think that also demonstrates the view of the Senate with respect to procedures and form and substance-that the House of Representatives is more the house of form. Perhaps the Senate is more the house of procedure and substance and people standing up on minor points and having some victory, whereas the House sees its role very much as the defender of the rights of the people in choosing their government. The specific catalyst for the current inquiry was the dispute over the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4) 1993. In that bill the Senate proposed changes to the income tax provisions that would provide deductions for expenditure incurred by life insurance companies and registered organisations in obtaining premiums which are excluded from assessable income. The view was taken that this, and another amendment dealing with taxpayers paying instalments earlier, could fall within the ambit of section 53(3) and was therefore yet another example of disagreement between the houses; and so the committee established its inquiry. The broader issue was touched on at that time by the Speaker in the House when he reported that there was disagreement between the houses over this bill. That was the historic relationship

theText: You will probably make yourself a QC at some point, just before you lose theWednesdaY,8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1913 between the houses, which he also wanted to be canvassed in the report; and the report does so comprehensively. One could say that a substantial part of the report deals with our historic relationship with the Senate and the place that the House of Representatives has in the Australian democracy. The principle behind section 53(3) is to ensure that the democratically elected lower house maintains its financial imperative over the democratically elected upper house that does not bear responsibility of government. I repeat that, because it is extraordinarily important to understand that in the end this report comes out very much as a House of Representatives report. One of the things I want to touch on briefly later is that the Senate committee established into this matter is more than likely to come out with a different type of compact from the one the House of Representatives has come out with. That is because we in the House of Representatives understand that the responsibility of government is overwhelming; and that while the Senate might sometimes spend 38 hours in discussion, and spend two of those hours on legislation-while senators can speak at great length, and can drag things out for years in some circumstances-in the end the responsibility for whether governments rise or fall is in the House of Representatives. That is what the people are watching on election night to see who wins the election. That is very keenly felt by my colleagues, particularly in marginal seats. Of the member for Banks, the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) and I, I have the most marginal seat, but I am grateful to say that I am not particularly marginalnot less than two per cent. This principle also reflects the fact that Australia is not similar to Britain in its make-up, but is more akin to the United States. One of the historical misinterpretations of the past 100 years is that the Australian system is based on the British system of government. While we have a Westminster style government in terms of its executive and so on, when our federation was formed it was formed around the concept of a federation of states. That is nothing like Britain. Australia does not have an unaccountable upper house, because we do not have the hierarchicalstructureofBritain. Our system was formed around the United States system, with the federation of states electing senators to a democratically elected upper house, not an appointed one. That reflects the fact that we have a diverse population, that we are geographically enormous compared to Britain, and that in the late 1890s we were unwilling as a people to tolerate an appointed, unaccountable upper house. The principle goes back to our roots. It goes back very early in our formulation as a Commonwealth and as 'a country, when we tried to break from Britain. I would like to endorse the availability test as enunciated in the report by the committee, which basically states that where money is to be made available to the executive that would otherwise not be available but for the amendments of the Senate, then that is naturally an increase in the burden on the people and falls within the ambit of section 53. Some in the Senate and elsewhere will say that this is an extremely narrow test, that it perhaps goes too far in maintaining the financial imperative of the House of Representatives. However on balance the committee has decided, after taking evidence from vast numbers of people and hearing particularly detailed evidence from the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives, that this is the test that is most capable of application, in that it is clear and unambiguous. It does curtail the power of the Senate to amend bills that authorise expenditure. This is consistent with the principle of preserving the financial initiative of the House of Representatives and therefore I endorse it. MC 1914 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday,8 March 1995 This will bean area of disagreement between eminent thinkers and between the houses. I look forward to the Senate handing down its report and to seeing what it will come up with by way of a test that it will support in the application of section 53. The House's position is a useful starting point in the compact. I also support, directly from the report, the exploration of the feasibility of a compact between the houses. Such a compact, the first of its kind between the House and the Senate-as most of the compacts so far established are between the Senate and the government-would inject greater certainty into a situation which is currently quite fluid and leads to far too many, and an increasing number of, disagreements between the Houses. There are obvious difficulties that leap to mind with the compact. I do not think we are under any illusions about those. Firstly, as the compact is proposed by the House of Representatives, it is natural that some members of the Senate will immediately respond in a less than positive fashion. Some senators will approach it with suspicion, seeing the House as trying to reduce the flexibility of the Senate in dealing with bills. The other problem is a disagreement that currently exists between the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Clerk of the Senate. This will be probably be played out through the negotiations-over' a compact. The final problem will be the tardiness of previous governments, senates and houses to reach compacts with one another because of the lack of flexibility that might give in a political and constitutional sense. I did not want to speak for long today and I have spoken for longer than I expected. In conclusion I would like to commend the report to the Main Committee and ask it to take note of the report. I would like to commend the secretariat. This has been a very long and complicated deliberation, mainly because it took such a great deal of concentration and reading and listening. The committee did not drag it out, but it took much longer than expected to produce the exposure draft and, now, the exposure draft report. We expected to 'finish this report by late last year and the members of the secretariat have shown great forbearance in their continued support of the committee. I would like to thank them, as they have done very good job. I would also like to thank the chairman of the committee, the member for Banks, for the excellent work that he has done. The committee has, in the last 12 months, been more active than it has been for a long time, particularly in its reference of bills. about all the nice things my colleague was saying about him. It is important that we understand the nature of our committee system: that there is an opportunity from time to time for reasonably important recommendations to emerge from committee deliberations. To my mind, the exposure draft on the third paragraph of section 53 released by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is such a document. I commend the chairman, the honourable member for Banks, and the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams), who has also made a very significant contribution in this debate. I would like to commend those who participated in the seminar, which was held in this very room. It was quite a fascinating experience. Regrettably I could not stay for all of it, but it was held on 28 October 1994 and it brought together academics, parliamentary staff and practising politicians in a way that, unfortunately, does not happen often enough. There was an opportunity to look at the way in which, in this instance, the constitution applies to the relationships between the two chambers.

theText: but he should not let it go to his head: I am a bit concernedWednesdaY,8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1915 There is no doubt that a lot of people contributed to this report. In saying that, let me not omit the staff. The staff of the standing committee have done an outstanding job and Michael Wright, who has now returned to other fields in the bureaucracy, has made a particular contribution in support. He came to us from the Attorney-General's Department and was a certainly a very valuable member of staff for the preparation of this report. But I want to say something a bit beyond that, and I do not want to repeat what others have said. The first thing is that it is very important for us all to register that, as politicians, we tend very much to get bogged down in the day-to-day consideration of those matters which are either on the blue sheet or the Notice Paper and are identified for our consideration for debate within our two chambers. In a bicameral system, we do not have a great deal of contact on a day-to-day basis with people in the other chamber. There are people such as the honourable member for Moncrieff( Mrs Sullivan) who have, in fact, been members of both chambers, but she is the exception. While there are a few in our House who have been members in the Senate, and a few in the Senate who have been members of the lower house, we tend to operate very much in parallel, rather than in tandem. It was the nature of a bicameral system, and the objectives of it, that, to my mind, emerged in perhaps a new form in looking back at the proceedings of some of those early constitutional conventions. It is quite fascinating looking back at the words of Henry Parkes and Robert Garran and some of those constitutional fathers and looking at what happens in the United States, the United Kingdom and elsewhere to see how they developed for us a constitution which has served Australia remarkably well. There, of course, are areas of difficulty in interpretation and I will deal with the particular one we are considering shortly. But the important part about it is that, essentially, in this bicameral system of ours, the constitutional fathers set down what they saw as the best way by which an effective day-to-day operation could be achieved. That was, to give both houses, as far as possible, equal powers, equal responsibilities, with a different method of election, but giving to the House alone the responsibility, essentially, for money and financial matters. In determining how far that peculiar responsibility for the administration of the economy lies within the House of Representatives, they set down a number of restraints. Section 53 of the constitution essentially identifies the way in which those constitutional fathers saw fit to define the difference. And it is important that we look back, as this report attempts, at the words that they used, and at why 'proposed burden or charge on the people' is used. That is really the only way in which you can interpret the words. It is important, too, that we understand that within that same constitution, they determined that matters such as section 53, relating to the administration of the powers of each chamber and the relationship between them, essentially are for the parliament itself to determine. From that, you come to the position of determining what is going to happen when the two houses have a different view on a particular matter. As my colleague the honourable member for Sturt( Mr Pyne) just mentioned, the origin of this reference was the most recent of those occasions when there was a difference between the two chambers. It concerned whether there should be a request or whether there could be an amendment by the Senate to a particular item of legislation. In this instance, it was the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4) 1993. But the importance is that, if there should be an impasse between the houses, there is demonstrably a difference between the consequences of a request and those of an amendment. MC 1916 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 March 1995 And as a result of an amendment and a failure to pass a bill, there are other constitutional steps that inevitably lead to a process which can generate a double dissolution, a joint sitting of the two houses, and a government's capacity to implement its will through the devices that the constitution lays down. In fact, what we are looking at is a process to ensure there will be certainty to avoid an impasse. That does not mean that we are going to have confusion as to whether the Senate is or is not in the right when it wishes to refuse passage, and after 1975 I think it is important that we rely less on those reserve powers of the Governor General. People are talking about the republic, inappropriate as I believe the action of the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) to be in doing so in Germany-in fact, I think that is something that is beyond the pale. The man does not seem to have any understanding of the responsibilities that should be his as Prime Minister. There has been a long-existing convention that you do not talk about matters pertaining to domestic politics when you are abroad and he would know of that convention. It is a pity he does not observe it. The point that I am making is that in the change it becomes very important that we consider just where those reserve powers of the Governor General, as exercised by Sir John Kerr in 1975, are going to have parameters. One of the parameters, in its way, lies in this very term of reference. What we are talking about here is an area where we are trying to remove doubt as to the powers of the Senate, and the more precision we as politicians can give to the constitution, the less those reserve powers, unwritten as they are, are going to be called on. SoI think, in its way, this is a far more significant report, and the issue is far more significant, than perhaps is suggested by the narrowness of the words and the question of the definition of words and the interpretation that the courts and academics and successive clerks of the House and those who are with them have put on the sentences. I have been involved as Leader of the House on a number of occasions on matters which in fact identify some of these same problems. It is not a matter which pertains only to a Labor government. So the issues are ongoing and it is a matter which governments of both persuasions need to address. The fact that there is now a report does not mean we identify to the nth degree exactly what these words mean. There is an imprecision in them. It is any proposed law, it is not any law, and any proposed charge or burden on the people. There is an historical reference. Apparently 'burden on the people' is one of those rhetorical phrases that Henry Parkes used to effect. The difficulty was that he died before this particular convention was in fact implemented. Be that as it may, the words do seem to us a little archaic. They are not the ordinary phrases that you use in the back bar down at the Royal, but they are certainly phrases that do have a legal application and, in analysing the application of those words, we have attempted to come to conclusions on it. I see that the honourable member for Tangney has returned to the Main Committee. He raised in his contribution in the parliament the other day one of the other real issues which concerns me and which briefly we have addressed in this report, and that is the extent to which under the present government there has been a marked propensity to transfer financial responsibility from the House of Representatives to the Senate. My particular concern is that expenditure measures understanding appropriations are initiated in the Senate, and we have made a recommendation in respect to that. I think that the government needs to be very careful in the way in which it in fact structures its ministry and then allocates portfolios which require measures which have financial Wednesday, 8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1917 implications. I instance Senator Collins and thportfolio of primary industries and energy. His portfolio responsibility frequently requires legislation which imposes a charge or a burden on the people. As far as I am concerned, if the minister is going to be in that other chamber, that minister has to forgo the capacity to introduce legislation which can run foul of the restraints that are imposed by section 53 of the constitution. The government has not done so and, to the degree that there is a problem, I believe the government has exacerbated it by its portfolio allocation and by the degree to which legislation is introduced at this stage in the other place when it would more appropriately be introduced in the House of Representatives. For a party that purports not to believe in a bicameral system and to want to abolish the Senate, it is even more paradoxical that it allocates portfolios in a way which means that legislation is introduced into the Senate which inevitably generates the conflict. The other issue that I want briefly to identify is that there has been-both in the seminar, to which reference has been made, and in the report-some discussion about whether or not the particular provisions of paragraph 3 of section 53 are justiciable. It is because there are doubts about the extent to which it may be. Reference has been made by the honourable member for Banks, and in the report, to those areas where, it suggested, it may well be justiciable .. The important thing is that there is a capacity for the houses of parliament to ensure that, in fact, that question does not arise, and that is by agreeing to a compact. I do not doubt that interpretations between the two chambers may well differ, and I hope that the process that has been enunciated and the draft compact that is set out in the back of the report do give a basis on which we may be able to come to some final resolution of the problem. I also commend the fact-and the honourable member for Tangney referred to it the other day-that, while there has been a compact before, in this instance the compact should be between the two chambers, rather than between the government and the Senate. The chart that is set out on page 152, which provides a flow chart of the committee's recommendations, is a chart which I hope that the Senate committee responsible for this particular area will identify and consider. If it has problems, perhaps we can enter into some discussions on those and see whether we can try to overcome the whole question of the imprecision which, in its present words, section 53 produces. I think this report does provide a basis for a compact. The chapter 13 identification of the components of it is an excellent basis; If there are problems, they are, demonstrably, for us to resolve. Section 50 of the constitution states: Each House of the Parliament may make rules and orders with respect to ... It very much embraces the idea of this compact. So we have the power to do it and we have the capacity to do it. I only hope the Senate has the will. constitution at the 1891 convention and the conventions of 1897 and 1898 spent a great deal of time debating what roles, respectively, the House of Representatives and the Senate should have in relation to finance. . The result can probably be expressed in two broad propositions. The first is that bills imposing taxation and providing for expenditure of public funds should originate in the House of Representatives and should not be amended by the Senate. This preserves the financial responsibility of the House of Representatives.

theText: The founding fathers who drafted the AustralianMC 1918 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 March 1995 Interestingly, this' principle probably had its constitutional origin in a resolution made by the House of Commons in 1678. The resolution was to the following effect: That all aids and supplies, and aids to His Majesty in Parliament, are the sole gift of the Commons; and all bills for the granting of any such aids and supplies ought to begin with the Commons; and that it is the undoubted and s.ole right of the Commons to direct, limit and appoint in such bills the ends, purposes, considerations, conditions, limitations and qualifications of such grants, which ought not to be changed or altered by the House of Lords. It is 1678 language, no doubt, but the similarity to the provisions of section 53 of our constitution is evident. The second broad proposition is that laws imposing taxation and laws effecting ordinary annual appropriations for government services should deal only with those subjects and, in the case of taxation laws, only with one subject of taxation. This principle protects the Senate from what is known as 'tacking': the addition of extraneous matters to a bill which the Senate cannot alter. This principle also has a relatively ancient constitutional origin in a resolution of the House of Lords in 1702. That resolution, which was somewhat shorter, in effect said: The annexing of any clause or clauses to a bill of aid or supply, the matter of which is foreign to and different from the matter of the said bill of aid or supply, is unparliamentary, and tends to the destruction of constitutional government. It is a noteworthy point that the House of Lords in 1702 thought that the technique of tackingconstitutional government and that is a point that is worthy of repetition now. The first proposition is to be found in more detail in section 53 and the second proposition is to be found in succinct terms in sections 54 and 55 of the constitution. At the time of the convention debates, it was recognised that disputes might arise. It was agreed that when the dispute concerned parliamentary procedures such as a matter between the two houses or a matter within a house, the courts had no role in dispute resolution. In order to highlight the distinction between matters which were for parliament to determine alone and those in respect of which the High Court might have had a constitutional role, the distinction was drawn in the language of the constitution between what were called 'proposed laws' and what were caIIed 'laws'. In section 53, dealing with the House's financial initiative, the expression used WaS 'proposed laws'. Somewhat anomalously, however, a distinction was drawn in section 54 and section 55 dealing with the protection of the Senate against tacking. The expression 'proposed laws' was used in respect of appropriation bills in section 54, but in section 55 the reference was to 'laws' imposing taxation. The result has been that sections 53 and 54 have generally been regarded as non-justiciable. It has been for the High Court to determine whether an act imposing taxation deals with the imposition of taxation only. Disputes have arisen from to time in relation to both section 53 and section 55. There were significant examples in 1993. The dispute in relation to section 55 occurred when the government introduced a bill which dealt with a range of taxing proposals including proposals to increase the rate of tax under the Fringe Benefits Tax 1986, the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1986 and the Medicare Levy Act 1986. This was plainly an attempt by the then Treasurer to deny the Senate's right to consider one subject of taxation in one bill uncomplicated by other

This action was in fact a catalyst for the referral to the legal and constitutional committees of both the House of Representatives and the Senate of the subject of the interpretation and application of section 53, which is the subject of the report of the House of Representatives committee under consideration now. The Senate this time did make amendments, or purport to make amendments. I was dealing with. I mentioned that there was another difference of view in relation to section 53 concerning the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1994. The Senate this time did make amendments and the Speaker indicated to the House, when the bill came from the Senate, that there was doubt as to whether the Senate had power to propose amendments rather than to request them. The House refrained from insisting on the Senate making requests only, in view of the public interest in the particular legislation being properly passed. The two examples of section 53 disputes that I have referred to highlight the fact that disputes can arise frequently. They also demonstrate that the houses can, between themselves, resolve the differences by compromise. If section 53 were justiciable, that might not be possible because a court would be obliged to determine whether the requirements of the constitution had been complied with or not. That is not to say that it is to be totally excluded that a court might get involved in determination of the validity of the procedures under section 53. If a bill is non-contentious, it may not be of much practical consequence whether the Senate purports to amend the bill in breach of section 53 or whether, in compliance with the section, it requests the House to amend it. It may be otherwise if the bill is contentious. Where a request is appropriate, the Senate may determine the fate of the bill but not its form. Where the Senate has power to amend, it may determine the form but not its ultimate fate.

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: Before the suspension I was in mid-sentence, so I will go back to theMC 1920 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 March 1995 One issue considered in the report is whether the Senate could resolve any section 53 issues simply by requesting amendments instead of making them. That is not, in my view, consistent with the intention of the constitution. It has to be borne in mind that the actions of the Senate may be significant for the purposes of section 57, the double dissolution provision. In the report, this issue is actually considered. It is pointed out that, where a Senate request is not complied with, the Senate bears the responsibility of determining the fate of the bill. It may drop the request or veto the whole bill. The House may accept the request, even if it is of the view that the Senate could have amended the bill. We have a precedent of that in 1994. The contrary argument is that, if the Senate can amend the bill, it should not be able to request an amendment in order to retain its ability to veto the bill altogether. In that situation, it seems to me, and I think the report reflects my view, that it would be open to the House to refuse to consider the request and to return the bill to the Senate, requiring it either to amend the bill or to return the bill unamended. That course does not seem ever to have been taken. There may also be other implications in relation to section 57. If the Senate makes a request when it could amend, that may be considered a failure to pass the proposed law, thereby invoking or at least putting in train the double dissolution procedure. The question also arose in the committee's deliberations as to whether the Senate can press a request for an amendment to a bill. Section 53 provides that the Senate may at any stage return to the House of Representatives any proposed law which the Senate may not amend, requesting amendment, and the House may make any amendment with or without modifications. The pressing of requests is an issue which has not been formally resolved between the two houses, although there have been views expressed on the issue-and they are referred to in the report-by Sir Robert Garran, Sir Isaac Isaacs and Sir John Latham. The House has never conceded the Senate's right to repeat and press or insiston'a request for an amendment in a bill which it may not amend. The fourth paragraph of section 53 permits the Senate to make a request at any stage. The view expressed by Sir Isaac Isaacs was that, once the Senate has made a request in relation to a particular issue, its power of suggestion is exhausted as far as that stage is concerned. The committee, in agreeing with that view, also agreed with the meaning attributed to 'stage'; that is, it refers to recognised stages in the passage of a bill through the chamber The effect is that a subsequent request relating to a matter may not be repeated at one stage, but at a subsequent stage. (Extension of time granted) The effect of this is that although the Senate has a capacity to repeat a request for the sa,me amendment more than once, it cannot do it more than once at the one stage in the proceeding of the bill through the Senate. , Anoth-r potential issue arises in relation to section 57 in that the pressing of a request by the Senate could constitute conduct on the part of the Senate constituting a failure to pass for the purposes of section 57. In his contribution to this debate, the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) referred to the financial responsibility oftheHouse. In my first contribution on the tabling of the exposure draft report in the House, I also mentioned that subject. I pointed out that it is ironic that at a time when a House committee is seeking to identify and protect the financial initiative of the House of Representatives, the House seems to be giving away any responsibility in relation to the financial scrutiny of government. In the, recent 22-year period, there has ,been a dramatic decline in the time devoted by the House of Representatives to the main appropriation bill. An average of 60 hours was spent Wednesday,8 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MCl921 in each of the 10 years prior to the Hawke government being elected. In the first 10 years of the Hawke and Keating Labor governments, that average time diminished to 36 hours. The second reading debate time went down from approximately 65 per cent of the time in the first IO-year period to 47 per cent of the time in the second 1O-year period. In 1993, the total time spent on the main appropriation bill was a mere 27 hours and some minutes. The bill was guillotined through. The committee stage at that time was guillotined in a way that, for significant departments, only six speakers could speak at an average of five minutes each. That was the sum total of the contribution of the House of Representatives to the scrutiny of the budget of those departments. In 1994, the picture was similar in respect of consideration in detail. The total time spent by the House on the main appropriation bill was a mere 24 hours and some minutes and only just over a quarter of that, six hours 45 minutes, was spent on consideration in detail. When we contemplate that the budgeted revenue was $109 billion, and the budgeted outlays were $121 billion, the amount of time spent on a dollar per unit of time basis is absolutely abysmal. SinceI am speaking in the Main Committee, I would like to repeat a suggestion I made in an earlier speech in the House, which is that there is scope for the involvement of the Main Committee in the consideration of the budget. The budget is now considered in the budget session. It is brought down in early May and then there are, at most, about four weeks projected for budget debate before the House rises at the end of the budget session. Given the legislative log jam that occurs at the end of any session-and it is no different in the budget session-time is not available for detailed consideration of the budget. The experience of 1993 was depressing for speakers-I suspect it was so on the government side as well as on the opposition side. Only five minutes per department meant that the number of speakers and the range of their subjects in the 1994 budget detailed consideration was even less than in 1993. It is a matter that I commend to Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins and to the Procedure Committee for future consideration. I would also like to see some means whereby an estimates procedure is introduced in the House so that the House, which has constitutional responsibility for financial initiatives in the parliament, exercises its responsibility instead of abdicating it in favour of the Senate.
